comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Hi Howard33, No, they really are store guides for what used to be the largest department store in Sydney, Anthony Hordern's. If you follow the link to the photographic collection above you can enlarge this photo (on the 2nd page of images) and see that their badges say 'store guide'. You'll also find other images of the activities in and around Anthony Hordern's, including annual sports days. physical culture classes, balls and the crowning of 'Miss Hordernia'. Life as a department store worker has certainly changed in the last 70 years or so!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: So you go into a department store and tell a guide that you need widget, and she guides you to the widget department? Interesting concept. My father worked in department stores most of his life. He trimmed windows and did in-store displays when I was born. (1933). He worked in their different stores, sometimes as a salesman and in 1946, he opened his own department store, so I guess you could say I grew up in those stores. I never saw a guide, but some stores had "floor walkers," men in nice suits who could steer you to the right department. One of his window displays from the 1940's. www.flickr.com/photos/howard33/3614986866/
